trans-unit.source: Use Resource Manager to allocate resources to the Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight| Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use Resource Manager to allocate resources to the Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight| Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Resource Manager for Spark clusters on HDInsight for better performance.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Resource Manager for Spark clusters on HDInsight for better performance.

trans-unit.source: Resource manager is a component of the Spark cluster dashboard that enables you to manage resources such as cores and RAM used by each application running on the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Resource manager is a component of the Spark cluster dashboard that enables you to manage resources such as cores and RAM used by each application running on the cluster.

trans-unit.source: From the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>, from the startboard, click the tile for your Spark cluster (if you pinned it to the startboard).
trans-unit.target: From the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>, from the startboard, click the tile for your Spark cluster (if you pinned it to the startboard).

trans-unit.source: You can also navigate to your cluster under Browse All > HDInsight Clusters.
trans-unit.target: You can also navigate to your cluster under Browse All > HDInsight Clusters.

trans-unit.source: From the Spark cluster blade, click Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: From the Spark cluster blade, click Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the admin credentials for the Spark cluster.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the admin credentials for the Spark cluster.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Launch Resource Manager</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Launch Resource Manager</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Here are some common scenarios that you might run into with your Spark cluster, and the instructions on how to address those using the Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Here are some common scenarios that you might run into with your Spark cluster, and the instructions on how to address those using the Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight is designed for multi-tenancy, so resources are split across multiple components (notebooks, job server, etc).
trans-unit.target: Apache Spark cluster in HDInsight is designed for multi-tenancy, so resources are split across multiple components (notebooks, job server, etc).

trans-unit.source: This allows you to use all Spark components concurrently without worrying about any component not able to get resources to run, but each component will be slower since resources are fragmented.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to use all Spark components concurrently without worrying about any component not able to get resources to run, but each component will be slower since resources are fragmented.

trans-unit.source: This can be adjusted based on your needs.
trans-unit.target: This can be adjusted based on your needs.

trans-unit.source: From the Spark Dashboard, click the Spark UI tab to find out the maximum number of cores and the maximum RAM that you can allocate to the applications.
trans-unit.target: From the Spark Dashboard, click the Spark UI tab to find out the maximum number of cores and the maximum RAM that you can allocate to the applications.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource allocation</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource allocation</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Going by the screen capture above, the maximum cores that you can allocate is 7 (total 8 cores of which 1 is in use), and the maximum RAM that you can allocate is 9GB (total 12GB RAM, of which 2GB must be set aside for system use and 1GB that is in use by other applications).
trans-unit.target: Going by the screen capture above, the maximum cores that you can allocate is 7 (total 8 cores of which 1 is in use), and the maximum RAM that you can allocate is 9GB (total 12GB RAM, of which 2GB must be set aside for system use and 1GB that is in use by other applications).

trans-unit.source: You should also factor any applications that are running.
trans-unit.target: You should also factor any applications that are running.

trans-unit.source: You can look at the running applications from the Spark UI tab.
trans-unit.target: You can look at the running applications from the Spark UI tab.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Running applications</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Running applications</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the HDInsight Spark Dashboard, click the Resource Manager tab and specify the values for Default application core count and Default executor memory per worker node.
trans-unit.target: From the HDInsight Spark Dashboard, click the Resource Manager tab and specify the values for Default application core count and Default executor memory per worker node.

trans-unit.source: Set other properties to 0.
trans-unit.target: Set other properties to 0.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource allocation</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource allocation</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Specify thrift server core Count and thrift Server executor memory as 0.
trans-unit.target: Specify thrift server core Count and thrift Server executor memory as 0.

trans-unit.source: With no core or memory allocated, the thrift server will go into a WAITING state.
trans-unit.target: With no core or memory allocated, the thrift server will go into a WAITING state.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource allocation</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource allocation</linkText>
